awd_titl_txt: Creating Pathways from College to Careers in Mathematics and Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will contribute to the national need for well-educated scientists, mathematicians, engineers, and technicians by supporting the retention and graduation of high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need at Portland Community College (PCC). PCC is the largest institution of higher education in Oregon. Over its five-year duration, this project will fund one-year scholarships to 108 students who are pursuing associate degrees in the biological, physical or mathematical sciences, with the expectation that 36 students (3 cohorts of 12 students) will receive these scholarships for two years, with 36 one-year scholarships awarded to these scholars transferring to Portland State University (PSU). The project will implement evidence-based project activities from recruitment to degree completion and transfer, such as targeted recruitment from local high schools, a comprehensive mentoring program from high school to PSU, enhanced faculty-student interactions, academic excellence workshops, and use of peer tutors. In addition, the project team will embed hands-on activities in PCC's mathematics curriculum related to culturally responsive teaching/learning that lower barriers to participation for women and other underrepresented students in STEM fields. The project will investigate the effectiveness of recruitment and retention strategies and other evidence-based approaches in broadening participation of underrepresented students by designing activities for a diverse pool of scholars. Furthermore, it will create a bridge between high school, PCC, and PSU, thus providing students with consistent exposure to STEM academic fields and careers and a built-in cohort for peer networking and support.

The aim of this project is to increase success of students pursuing STEM degrees by implementing evidence-based strategies, such as 1) collaborating with local high schools to provide additional support and encouragement of participants in entering post-secondary education, and 2) embedding peer mentors in introductory PCC math courses to begin cohort-building activities that continue throughout the scholarship program as most community colleges are not residential, thus effecting students' ability to persist in STEM. The project will make curricular changes to two introductory math courses taken by students majoring in STEM, and will investigate the degree to which these changes impact retention, with an expectation that there will be an overall increase in the percentage of students passing the course. It is anticipated that 85% of scholars will be retained from their first to their second year due to the curricular changes and intensive supports provided to them. The project will be assessed using qualitative methods such as surveys, guided interviews, and focus groups with scholars and faculty; and quantitative measures such as pass rates of targeted math courses and scholar retention and transfer rates. This project is funded by NSF's Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics program, which seeks to increase the number of low-income academically talented students with demonstrated financial need who earn degrees in STEM fields. It also aims to improve the education of future STEM workers, and to generate knowledge about academic success, retention, transfer, graduation, and academic/career pathways of low-income students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The C2CiMS project focused on three core activities: recruiting promising students, providing math support services, and increasing retention, completion, and transfer rates of STEM students. Over the 5-year grant period, 46 students were recruited with 33 students having completed studies at PCC and transferred to other 4-year universities within the STEM field. Over two-thirds of the participants and 81% of transfer students identify as first-generation college students. Retention rates for C2CiMS students were significantly higher than the general PCC population. Financial aid, scholarships, tutoring, and regular cohort meetings were identified as critical support for retention.

During the recruitment period, a topic worth further discussion arose as whether the scholarship should prioritize demonstrated STEM talent or financial need. Data suggests prioritizing financial need over STEM talent tends to result in lower retention rate within the STEM field at community college level. One of the most often mentioned reasons for students enrolling at PCC is low cost. Most mentioned barriers for retention include difficulty of subject matter, financial and time constraints, and lack of support from family and friends. Students cited teacher recommendations as a significant factor in their decision to enroll at PCC as well as participating in our scholarship program. Students who completed the program reported that scholarships and financial aid have the most impact on their success. 

The project targeted foundational math courses such as MTH 95 and MTH 111, which are key courses for STEM progression at PCC. Data suggests improved pass rates in classes with peer mentoring. Peer mentoring played a significant role in improving students’ math identity, confidence, and sense of belonging in the math community. Over 80% of peer mentors reported a positive impact on their math identity, with female students reporting the highest levels of positive change. This program not only benefited the mentees but also the mentors, who developed leadership skills and a stronger connection to their own academic and career goals. 

With the support of the grant, a series of professional development sessions were held, focusing on topics like inclusivity, equity, mental health, and collaborative learning. Faculty reported gains in knowledge, skills, and attitudes (KSA) that translated into improved teaching strategies. Instructors noted that professional development helped them create more supportive learning environments and encouraged the use of culturally responsive teaching practices.

The project made significant strides in supporting underrepresented students in STEM fields, improving math success rates, and enhancing faculty teaching practices. The professional development for math faculty and peer mentoring will be continued and expanded after the grant ends.

 


Last Modified: 02/05/2025
Modified by: Yongwen Lampert
